Graphical abstract In this work, PtxPd1-x (x = 0, 0.5, and 1) nanoparticles (NPs) were synthesized on the surface of SiO2@graphene oxide which covered by 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate ([bmim] PF6) ionic liquid (IL) layer. FT-IR spectroscopy, zeta potential, CHN elemental analysis, XRD, XPS, SEM, EDX, TEM, TGA, BET, and ICP-AES techniques were applied for the characterization of the multiphasic catalyst. The as-prepared nanocomposite was used as an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the oxidation of cyclohexene by molecular oxygen, as a green oxidant. Different experimental conditions such as oxygen pressure, reaction time, reaction temperature and amount of catalyst were investigated in this reaction. The bimetallic NPs showed the best catalytic activity in this reaction. The conversion and selectivity of 2-cyclohexene-1-one as main product were obtained to be 65% and 93% respectively, when the reaction was carried at 80 °C for 8 h. In the as-made multiphasic catalyst, IL layer not only enhanced the stability of NPs on the surface of catalyst, but also increased the catalytic performance due to the stabilization of the reaction intermediates. Among the different solvathochromic parameters, the normalized polarity ( E T N ) and the hydrogen-bond acceptor ability (β) of IL are the most important properties which improve the role of the IL as a co-catalyst in this reaction. This multiphasic catalyst, which has the advantages of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalytic systems, can be easily separated from the reaction media and reused for five consecutive runs without losing the catalytic performance. Abbreviations MOFs Metal organic frameworks NPs nanoparticles BMNPs bimetallic nanoparticles GO graphene oxide ILs ionic liquids APPTS 3-(2-aminoethylamino) propyltrimethoxysilane GC gas chromatograph FID flame ionization detector Cy-one 2-cyclohexene-1-one Cy-ol 2-cyclohexene-1-ol epoxy epoxycyclohexane HBD hydrogen bond donor HBA hydrogen bond acceptor TMS tetramethyl silane Keywords PtPd bimetallic nanoparticles Ionic liquids Multiphasic catalyst Cyclohexene oxidation Reaction kinetics 1 Introduction The catalytic oxidation of C–H bonds of alkenes and in particular cyclohexene, is an important reaction, which has widespread industrial applications. [1] Various chemical oxidants have been already applied for its oxidation include hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), t-butyl hydro-peroxide (TBHP) and others. [2] On the other hand, molecular oxygen and its potential as green oxidant has many advantages compared to chemical oxidants, including its lower cost and higher availability, thus it has received much attention in similar oxidation processes. [3,4] Due to the existence of two active sites (CC double bond, and C–H bond) in the cyclohexene molecule, it is difficult to control the type of produced oxygenated products [5]. Among of these products, 2-cyclohexene-1-one (Cy-one) is an added-value product, which is crucial for its application in chemical and pharmaceutical industries [6]. Homogeneous catalysts are a suitable match for the study of the reaction mechanisms, but their recovery from the reaction media is difficult. [7,8] As an alternative, heterogeneous catalysts have been developed, in order to exploit the apparent advantages, such their easy separation, recovery and reuse, as well as the potentially milder reaction conditions [9,10]. Over the last years, many catalysts have been employed for the selective oxidation of cyclohexene, including metal organic frameworks (MOFs), metal nanoparticles (NPs), metal oxides such as CeO2, Al2O3, Co3O4, CuO2, TiO2, SiO2 and CuO, which have exhibited high catalytic activity in this reaction. [11–18] Due to aggregation trend of NPs, their application has seen a decrease [19]. Hence, their immobilization on various supports has shown a protective action and stability improvement [20]. Among the different supports, graphene oxide (GO) has been widely employed in heterogeneous catalysis because of its unique properties, such as the high thermal conductivity, mechanical strength, superior charge mobility, large specific surface area, chemical stability and the large density of free electrons [21,22]. As such, NPs have been anchored on GO, exploiting its large surface area and abundant functional groups [23]. A series of different NPs have been used so far for catalytic reactions, including bimetallic NPs (CuNi, CoNi, AgNi, PtAu, AuPd, PtPd, etc.). [19,24–27] Due to the synergistic effect between two metals and the tunable physico-chemical properties of bimetallic NPs (BMNPs), they are considered as important mediators for the synthesis of catalysts with high activity and selectivity [19,24]. Also, the combination of metal NPs can modify the electronic and geometric distribution of metal sites, and therefore improve the catalytic performance in their application in heterogeneous systems. Recently, Au-Ag, Pd-Au, Pt-Pd, and Au-Pd BMNPs supported on different solid catalysts were reported as efficient catalysts for ethylene oxidation, aerobic oxidation of primary alcohols, glycerol oxidation and ethylbenzene oxidation, respectively. [28–31] In the heterogeneous catalytic reactions, the selectivity and catalytic activity can also be controlled by the reaction solvents. Therefore, the choice of solvents and the investigation of solvent effect are crucial topics that require a systematic investigation. [32,33] The interaction of solvents with the reactants and the surface of the catalyst is an important issue in all chemical reactions, but a deep understanding of the solvent effect is difficult, due to the different physical and chemical properties of the various solvents [34,35]. Ionic liquids (ILs) have been utilized as solvents in catalytic processes, in order to enhance the selectivity and reactivity of the reactions [36]. ILs, such as salt and ionic compounds, have unique properties including high viscosity, low toxicity, good ionic conductivity, high thermal stability and tunable solvent properties [37]. Nevertheless, due to their intrinsic characteristics, such as high cost and insufficient knowledge of their physico-chemical properties, the widespread application of ILs has been decreased. [38] When the ILs were applied as homogenous catalysts, the recovery of catalyst from the mixture is difficult [39]. In order to overcome this drawback, homogenous IL-based nanocomposites have been prepared by immobilization the ILs on the solid support [40]. Simply by coating a layer of ILs on the surface of catalyst, an cost-effective catalyst can be created. These catalysts are prepared with small amount of ILs and have exhibited the same catalytic activity as the bulk conditions. [41] However, there is a lack of documented cases on BMNPs preparation supported on ILs (BMNPs/ILs) with high activity in different catalytic reactions. It should also be noted that the shape, size and catalytic performance of NPs is depended on the reaction media, and IL is suitable for the preparation and stabilization of NPs [42]. Herein, we report a new preparation process of a multiphasic catalyst including IL, BMNPs and solid support, for implementation in oxidation reactions. More specifically, in the present work Pt, Pd, and bimetallic PtPd nanoparticles were anchored on the surface of SiO2@graphene oxide nanocomposite, which was coated by an IL layer (1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate). By using this method, we attempt to prepare a new multiphasic catalyst in order to exploit the advantages of homogenous and heterogeneous catalysts in the oxidation of cyclohexene. By this procedure, we can improve the catalytic performance of BMNPs in the presence of IL as co-catalyst. The new multiphasic catalyst has been characterized by a series of techniques and the catalytic performance of the as-prepared nanocomposite was assessed in cyclohexene oxidation reaction by molecular oxygen (Fig. 1 ). Finally, the influence of different reaction conditions, such as the molecular oxygen pressure, reaction temperature and time, as well as catalyst amount were investigated for the optimization of this reaction. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals and reagents Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), sodium borohydride (NaBH4), ammonium hydroxide solution (NH3.H2O), sodium nitrate (NaNO3), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), hydrogen peroxide solution (H2O2, 30% v/v), hydrochloric acid (HCl), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), Chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6.6 H2O), 2, 6-diphenyl-4-(2, 4, 6-triphenylpyridinium-1-yl) phenolate (Reichardt's dye 30), and all solvents (including ethanol, toluene, acetonitrile, and chlorobenzene) and cyclohexene were purchased from Merck. Graphite powder, and 3-(2-aminoethylamino) propyltrimethoxysilane (APPTS) were supplied by Fluka and Alfa Aesar, respectively. 4-Nitroanisole, and 4-Nitroaniline (Merck, 99%) were recrystallized from water/ethanol and water/acetone, respectively. Finally, 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate ([bmim] PF6) ionic liquid (IL), and palladium (II) chloride (PdCl2) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. 2.2 Analytical chemical and catalyst characterization techniques The phase purity and crystal structure of the products were evaluated by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) using a PW3050/60 X' Pert PRO diffractometer with a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54060 A°) in the 2Ө range of 5-80°. The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum in the range from 500 to 4000 cm−1 was recorded by an ABB BOMER series spectrophotometer. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used to measure the specific surface area of the as-prepared nanocomposite, and was determined by using BEL SORB-mini II at 77 K. The thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) curves was performed by a Mettler Thermogravimeter under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 15 °C min−1. The morphologies of the samples were characterized by the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Mira3 Tascan), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Philips CM30). A Malvern zetasizer Nano ZS instrument was utilized for measuring the surface charge of SiO2 and subsequently the functionalized SiO2 nanospheres. The elemental analysis of the catalyst was performed by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) on a Varian 730-ES spectrophotometer. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) analysis was performed by an AXIS NOVA photoelectron spectrometer (Kratos Analytical, Manchester, UK) using Al-Kɑ radiation. Also, 13C NMR (75 MHz) spectra were measured on a Bruker DRX 300 AVANCE spectrometer at room temperature by using DMSO-d 6 as a solvent. Finally, the UV–vis Cintra 40 spectrophotometer was applied for measurement of solvatochromic parameters. 2.3 SiO2 nanospheres: preparation and functionalization 2.3.1 Synthesis of the SiO2 nanospheres The SiO2 nanospheres were prepared according to the modified procedure as described by Stӧber et al. [43] Briefly, 25 mL of ethanolic solution containing 4 mL of NH3.H2O and 15.5 mL of H2O were mixed together under vigorous stirring for 30 min (solution A). In the other vial, 2.5 mL of TEOS was dissolved in ethanol (22.5 mL) (solution B). Afterward, solution B was added dropwise to solution A under mild stirring. In this process, ethanol was used as a solvent and ammonia acts as a catalyst in the preparation of the SiO2 nanospheres. The mixture was allowed to react for 12 h under magnetic stirring at room temperature, to produce white colloidal SiO2 nanospheres. The as-prepared products were separated by centrifugation, washed several times with water-ethanol mixture, and then dried at 50 °C in an oven. 2.3.2 Preparation of functionalized SiO2 nanospheres 1 g of as-synthesized SiO2 nanospheres was dispersed in 40 mL of toluene for 45 min. Afterwards, 2 mL of 3-(2-aminoethylamino) propyltrimethoxysilane (APPTS) was added into the above solution and refluxed at 120 °C for 12 h under argon (Ar) gas. After this time, the products were collected by centrifugation, washed tree times with ethanol and finally dried at 60 °C for 8 h. 2.4 Preparation of SiO2@graphene oxide (SiO2@GO) Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared from graphite by using a modification of the Hummer's method. [44] 60 mg of GO, and 200 mg of functionalized SiO2 nanospheres were dispersed separately in 100 mL of deionized water (DI) under sonication for 1 h. Afterwards, the mixture of SiO2 nanospheres was added dropwise into the aqueous solution of GO under mild sonication for 30 min at room temperature, followed by continuous stirring for 1 h to complete the self-assembly of GO sheets on the positively charged SiO2 nanospheres. Finally, the obtained GO-wrapped SiO2 nanospheres were collected by centrifugation, washed with DI water and dried at 50 °C in an oven. 2.5 Preparation of ionic liquid (IL) coated on SiO2@GO nanocomposite (IL/SiO2@GO) The as-made SiO2@GO nanocomposite was coated by ionic liquid layer via a facile liquid-impregnation method. At first, SiO2@GO (0.3 g) was dispersed in the mixture of ethanol and water (volume ratio of two solvents 1:1) for 20 min. Then, ionic liquid (2 mmol) was added to the above mixture under stirring. The mixture was continuously stirred for 12 h at 60 °C, until the all solvent was evaporated. The obtained product (IL/SiO2@GO) was gathered, and used in the next step. 2.6 Synthesis of PtxPd1-x (x = 0, 0.5, and 1) nanoparticles supported on IL/SiO2@GO For this step, 50 mg of as-prepared IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite was dispersed in 30 mL of DI water for 15 min, to obtain the IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite suspension. Afterwards, 2.3 mL of PdCl2 solution [0.01 M], and 1.2 mL of H2PtCl6.6 H2O solution [0.01 M] were taken and added slowly into the above homogeneous solution, under vigorous stirring. The pH value of the solution was adjusted to 12 by adding a NaOH solution [1 M] and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. Then, 500 μL of NaBH4 solution [0.25 M] was appended slowly into the mixture and stirred for 60 min at room temperature. Afterwards, the reaction mixture was refluxed at 95 °C for 6 h under air atmosphere. In this step, addition of NaOH solution and increasing the temperature (95 °C) can facilitate the reduction process of metal salts and preparation of BMNPs. The resulting product was collected by centrifugation and washed with ethanol and water until the metal ions residues were removed and then dried at 60 °C for 12 h. The same procedure was applied for the preparation of single metal nanoparticles (Pt, and Pd) supported on IL/SiO2@GO. Fig. 2 summarizes the preparation mechanism of the PtxPd1-x/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite. 2.7 Catalytic oxidation of cyclohexene The oxidation of cyclohexene over PtxPd1-x/IL/SiO2@GO (x = 0, 0.5, and 1) nanocomposites was carried out by molecular oxygen as a green oxidant in acetonitrile. More specifically, 0.6 mL of cyclohexene, 2 mL of acetonitrile, 0.5 mL of chlorobenzene as initial standard, and a certain amount of catalyst were transferred into the 25 mL stainless-steel autoclave equipped with a pressure indicator. Molecular oxygen was purged into the autoclave for 15 min to remove the air. Afterward, it was filled with different pressures of molecular oxygen and was heated to the required temperature under magnetic stirring. After the completion of the desired reaction time, the autoclave was moved from the oil bath to an ice bath for approx. 30 min and then molecular oxygen was released. Samples of the reaction solution were taken at various times and detected by a HP6890 gas chromatograph (GC) with 60 m HP5 column, using a flame ionization detector (FID). The analyses were performed under the following conditions: initial temperature 60 °C, rate 15 °C min−1, final temperature 250 °C, and gas flow 1.40 mL min−1. After the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation, washed several times with water/ethanol and finally dried at 60 °C for the next catalytic run under the same reaction conditions. The conversion of reaction, and selectivity of products including 2-cyclohexene-1-one (Cy-one), 2-cyclohexene-1-ol (Cy-ol), and epoxycyclohexane (epoxy) were calculated using the following equations: (1) C o n v e r s i o n = n C y c l , s t a r t - n C y c l , e n d n C y c l , s t a r t × 100 (2) S e l e c t i v i t y = n j ∑ n J × 100 In which, n C y c l and n j are the moles of cyclohexene and products, respectively. 2.8 Solvatochromic parameters measurement In order to evaluate the influence of ionic liquid layer on the surface of the nanocomposite, the solvatochromic parameters of [bmim] PF6 ionic liquid were obtained, and reported in Table 1 . In this method, [45] the solution of probes (including of 4-nitroaniline, 4-nitroanisole and Reichardt's dye) were prepared in ethanol and stored at 4 ± 1 °C in the dark glass. A proper amount of indicator solution was transferred into a quartz cell, and then was purged with N2 gas to remove the ethanol. Afterwards, the solvatochromic indicator was dissolved in the ionic liquid. The spectrophotometric measurements were performed on a UV–vis Cintra 40 spectrophotometer, and 1-cm optical path quartz cells were used at 298 K during the whole investigation. The Kamlet-Taft parameters, such as hydrogen bond donor (HBD) ability (α), hydrogen bond acceptor (HBA) ability (β), and dipolarity/polarizability (π∗ ) were calculated by the following equations (eqs. 3–5). [46] (3) π * = 0.427 ( 34.12 - ν A N S ) (4) α = 0.186 10.91 - ν B - 0.72 π * (5) β = 31.10 - 3.14 π * - ν A N I 2.79 where, ν ANS, νB , and ν ANI refer to the absorption behavior of 4-nitroanisole, Reichardt's dye, and 4-nitroaniline, respectively. Reichardt's dye has been utilized to determine the polarity of organic solvents and many different solvent mixtures. The molar transition energy of this probe can be computed by applying equation 6. This parameter normalized using tetramethylsilane (TMS) and water with value 1 and 0, respectively, according to equation 7. (6) E T ( 30 ) = 28591.5 λ m a x (7) E T N = E T S o l v e n t - E T ( T M S ) E T W a t e r - E T ( T M S ) = E T S o l v e n t - 30.7 32.4 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of the PtxPd1-x/IL/SiO2@GO catalyst At the first step of the preparation of the PtxPd1-x/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite, the surface of spherical SiO2 was modified by using APPTS in the presence of toluene under argon gas for 12 h. Due to the positive charge of the modified SiO2 nanospheres, the GO layer can be supported on the surface of SiO2 by mild sonication. Then, a layer of IL was coated on SiO2@GO catalyst by the liquid-impregnation method. In the last step, H2PtCl6. 6 H2O and PdCl2 solutions were used as metal sources for the synthesis of PtPd BMNPs by using the facile chemical/reflux method. It should be noted that, the adhesion of metal nanoparticles (NPs) on the surface of catalyst was improved, most probably due to the robust π-π interactions between imidazolium rings of the ionic liquid and GO, which plays an important role for the association between ionic liquid and GO (Fig. 3 a). Furthermore, the molecular structure of [bmim] PF6 is heavy and occupies a large space. This trait is favorable for the dispersion of metal NPs on the surface of catalyst via electrostatic repulsion (Fig. 3b). Also, this property can prevent the aggregation of metal NPs in the solution phase, which is an important parameter for their stabilization by IL. [42] The XRD patterns of the as-prepared samples are shown in Fig. 4 (a–f). The appearance one major peak around 10° (Fig. 4a) corresponds to the (001) plane of GO, which confirmed that the GO was successfully synthesized by the modified Hummers method. [44] The strong and broad diffraction peak at 2Ө = 24° in Fig. 4b, is related to the SiO2 nanosphere. This peak was observed clearly in all samples, which indicated that the coating of GO and the presence of the IL layer around the SiO2 nanospheres did not induce any phase change in the SiO2 nanostructure (Fig. 4, b–f). The three distinct peaks located at 2Ө = 40.04°, 46.53°, and 67.86° in the pattern of Pt/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite can be attributed to the (111), (200), and (220) plane of cubic nanostructure (space group Fm3m, a = b = c = 3.9161 A°) of Pt nanoparticles (JCPDS No. 00-001-1194). According to Fig. 4e, Pd NPs showed the similar peaks that coincide with those of fcc Pd (JCPDS No. 46-1043). [47] Strong diffraction peaks at 2Ө = 39.88°, 46.34° and 67.51° can be indexed to the (111), (200) and (220) crystalline planes of the PtPd bimetallic nanoparticles (BMNPs) [30]. It should be pointed out, the existence of (111) peak at 39.88° with an intermediate position between the (111) peak of Pt (40.04°), and the (111) peak of Pd (39.81°) is evidence of the formation of PtPd BMNPs on the surface of IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite. The crystalline size (d) of single, and bimetallic nanoparticles was obtained by using Scherer's equation (eq. 8). (8) d = 0.9 λ β c o s θ In this equation λ, β, and Ɵ are corresponding to the wavelength, the width at half maximum of peak, and the position of observed peak, respectively. The average diameter of Pt, Pd, and Pt0.5Pd0.5 NPs was estimated to be 3.21, 4.46, and 2.32 nm respectively. Presence of IL layer can protect the NPs, and BMNPs from aggregation. In addition, based on the ICP analysis, the content of Pt and Pd nanoparticles were found to be 4.5% and 4.8% in Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite, respectively. The FTIR spectra was recorded to prove the coating of IL layer on the surface of SiO2@GO nanocomposite (Fig. 5 , traces a, and b). As can be seen from the spectra of GO, the broad peak at 3500 cm−1 corresponds to stretching and bending vibration of OH groups. Also, the adsorption peaks centered at 1064 cm−1 (C–O), 1250 cm−1 (COH), 1410 cm−1 (C–O), 1625 cm−1 (CC), 1727 cm−1 (CO), and 2380 cm−1 (CO2) confirm the presence of oxygen containing functional groups in as-prepared GO.44 The FTIR spectra of IL/SiO2@GO (Fig. 5, trace b) depicts two sharp absorption peaks at 880 cm−1, and 1050 cm−1 which are attributed to the = C–H, and C–N bonds vibration of the IL layer on the surface of nanocomposite, respectively. The absorption bond around 1585 cm−1 is related to the CC vibration of the imidazole ring, which in turn confirms the presence of the IL layer. In addition, the peaks were observed at 1453 cm−1, 1630 cm−1, and 1642 cm−1 are related to C–N, CC, and CC stretching bonds of imidazolium cation, respectively. The two weak peaks which appear at 2820 cm−1 and 2928 cm−1 are assigned to the C–H vibration modes of IL layer in as-synthesized nanocomposite. [48] In fact, the presence of all functional groups were confirmed by using FTIR analysis, and indicated the successful loading of the IL in multiphasic catalyst. The materials morphology and structure were characterized by using FE-SEM, and TEM (Figs. 6 and 7 , respectively). Fig. 6A demonstrates the FE-SEM image of SiO2 nanospheres with an average particle size of 350 nm. Fig. 7 illustrates the TEM images of the prepared SiO2@GO samples. The products are clearly spherical particles with uniform size, without any aggregation, which are in good agreement with the SEM results (Fig. 6B). As also shown in Fig. 7 (A and B), a tiny layer of graphene oxide was also exhibited on the surface of SiO2. In comparison with the smooth surface of pure SiO2 nanospheres, the demonstrated external surface roughness of SiO2@GO confirmed the deposition of GO sheets on the SiO2 surface (Fig. 6B). In addition, from the TEM images of PtPd/SiO2@GO nanocomposite, it is clear that PtPd BMNPs with size in the range of 1.5–2 nm were distributed onto the surface of SiO2@GO (Fig. 7, C and D). The “bloated” structures of IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposites, confirmed the loading of the IL onto the surface of SiO2@GO (Fig. 6, C and D). Also, compared to the catalyst without the IL layer, the presence of this layer on the surface of catalyst was clearly observed in the TEM images of Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposites (Fig. 7, E and F). According to these images, the whole surface of catalyst (SiO2@GO) was completely covered by an IL layer that improved the stability of NPs and provided multiphasic catalyst. Provisionally, we can suggest that this is a method with great prospect for the preparation of multiphasic catalysts, with potentially high catalytic performance. In order to study the valence state of the metal nanoparticles in Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite, XPS analysis was applied. Fig. 8 illustrates the XPS spectra of Pt 4f, and Pd 3d in the as-made sample. In the spectrum of Pt 4f, the two main peaks that appeared at 71.13 eV and 74.20 eV are related to the Pt 4f7/2, and Pt 4f5/2 of Pt°, respectively (Fig. 8a). Moreover, the other peaks located at 72.86 eV and 75.94 eV are assigned to the Pt2+ species from the PtO and/or Pt (OH)2. [30,47] As can be seen from the Pd 3d spectrum (Fig. 8b), the binding energies of Pd° were observed at 335.21 eV (Pd 3d5/2) and 340.50 eV (Pd 3d3/2). Similarly, the peaks that appeared at 337.54 eV and 342.40 eV are attributed to the Pd2+ species in the as-prepared multiphasic catalyst. [49] The presence peaks of Pt2+, and Pd2+ can be related to the incomplete reduction of metal and facile oxidation of nanoparticles (Pt and Pd) under ambient conditions. It should be pointed out that the binding energies of Pt 4f, and Pd 3d were slightly changed for this catalyst and showed a negative shift when compared respectively with the bulk Pt (71.7 eV and 75 eV) and Pd (335.6 eV, and 341.1 eV). [50] Due to the electronic interaction between two metals with different electro negativities (Pd = 2.20, and Pt = 2.28) and the formation of BMNPs, the electronic properties of Pt and Pd were modified and this shift can be observed. [30] XPS results confirmed that, the PtPd BMNPs were successfully prepared on the surface of IL/SiO2@GO by the reported method. In order to investigate the organic components content of the prepared nanocomposites, the elemental analysis of carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen (CHN analysis) was performed. The percent of hydrogen, carbon and nitrogen of samples including SiO2@GO, and Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO are given in Table 2 . As it can be seen from the obtained results, by coating the IL layer on the SiO2@GO, the amount of carbon and hydrogen was increased, which confirmed the IL layer was coated successfully on the surface of catalyst. Due to presence of nitrogen in IL structure, the amount of nitrogen reached 3.59% in the Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite. According to the nitrogen content, the loading of IL was 1.218 mmol g−1. Furthermore, the zeta potential values of the SiO2 nanospheres and the functionalized SiO2 by APPTS were measured to be -12.5 mV, and + 21.8 mV, respectively, when dispersed in DI water (Fig. 9 ). Based on the above results, the positively charged functionalized SiO2 nanospheres were easily adsorbed to the negative surface of graphene oxide (-55.4 mV) [51] with a large amount of hydroxyl, carboxyl and epoxy groups, and a thin layer of graphene oxide was coated on the surface of SiO2 nanospheres. These results indicated that the catalyst was successfully synthesized step by step. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was applied to evaluate the composition of samples. The TGA plots of GO, SiO2@GO, and IL/SiO2@GO are shown in Fig. 10 A. Due to the pyrolysis of the oxygen-containing functional groups, the measured weight loss was around 50% for GO. In contrast with GO, the SiO2@GO and IL/SiO2@GO catalysts showed a good thermal stability. The TGA result of the IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite indicated that at temperature below 250 °C, the total weight loss was only 6.5%. This result confirmed that in the optimum temperature for this reaction (80 °C), the as-prepared multiphasic catalyst was completely stable and there is no weight loss expected. Also, from the TGA analysis the loading of IL was calculated to be 1.02 mmol g−1, which is in good agreement with the obtained value from CHN analysis. The last step in the complete characterization of the catalyst was the specific surface area measurements by BET. The surface area and the total pore volume of Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite were studied by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 10B) while the sample was outgassed at 100 °C for 5 h under vacuum, before to N2 adsorption. These values were 42.775 m2 g−1 and 0.1395 cm3 g−1, respectively. It should be noted that the catalyst without IL layer (Pt0.5Pd0.5/SiO2@GO) had much higher surface area (58.913 m2 g−1), and pore volume (0.1721 cm3 g−1) than Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite. The pore size distribution is dependent on the functional groups on the surface of catalyst, while the total pore volume of the different samples decreased through anchoring the functional groups.[[52]] This value is low in the as-prepared catalyst, due to the presence of the IL layer. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the as-prepared nanocomposites: Step-wise study of cyclohexene oxidation by means of the synthesized catalyst The as-prepared samples including Pt/SiO2@GO, Pd/SiO2@GO, Pt/IL/SiO2@GO, Pd/IL/SiO2@GO, Pt0.5Pd0.5/SiO2@GO and Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO were used as catalysts in cyclohexene oxidation reaction, using O2 as a green oxidant. The obtained results are reported in Table 3 . According to the obtained results, the loading of BMNPs on the surface of IL/SiO2@GO can improve the conversion of cyclohexene. The conversion of reaction reached 65% over the Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite. In the presence of the nanocomposite without the IL layer, the conversion of the reaction was 50%, which indicated the critical role of IL as a co-catalyst in cyclohexene oxidation. High conversion and selectivity of Cy-one were observed for the as-made samples in decreasing order: Pt0.5Pd0.5 < Pt < Pd. This result indicated that the composition of NPs has a key role in their catalytic activity. It is very interesting that by coating the IL layer the catalytic performance of monometallic NPs in cyclohexene oxidation was increased, which confirmed the role of IL in this reaction. Also, due to the presence of IL layer on the surface of solid support (SiO2@GO) which protected the NPs from aggregation, the BMNPs with the small size, and high activity were obtained. Due to the synergistic effect between the two metals and the tunable physico-chemical properties of the BMNPs, the Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite showed the best performance in this catalytic reaction with high reactivity and selectivity. In the BMNPs systems, by the addition of the second metal, due to the variation of the electronic and microstructural features, not only the suitable interaction between the substrates and surface of NPs was provided, but also the stabilization of the intermediates in catalytic reaction showed an increase. Moreover, the electronic interactions between the two metal NPs with varied geometric effects can enhance their catalytic performance in the oxidation reaction. [53,54] Among the different catalysts in this study, the lowest activity in cyclohexene oxidation was observed for the Pd NPs. Meanwhile, by introducing Pt NPs and the formation of BMNPs, the activity was increased in the cyclohexene oxidation reaction. In order to evaluate the activity of the as-prepared nanocomposites, the pseudo-first order rate constants (kapp ) were calculated by using Eq. 9 as follows: (9) ln C t C 0 = k a p p t In which Ct, and C0 are the concentration at time t, and 0 respectively. The plots of ln(Ct/C0) against reaction time (t) have a good linear correlation, which validated the pseudo-first order kinetics (Fig. 11 ). As we know, the cyclohexene oxidation is a radical process [55] and the same pathway is demonstrated here when the Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO catalyst was applied in this reaction. At the first step of this mechanism, the ɑ-H atom of cyclohexene is removed and a C6H9 ● radical is obtained. This radical can react with molecular oxygen, controlled by diffusion. The initial step of this mechanism is carried out by the BMNPs. Our results illustrated that the bimetallic nanocomposites are much more efficient for oxidation of cyclohexene than Pt and/or Pd NPs alone. Due to the different electron density of the catalyst active sites in presence of both metals, the BMNPs are more capable to generate the C6H9 ● radical. Also, our results confirmed the synergistic effect between the two metals that improved their catalytic performance in this reaction. According to the obtained results, the rate constant value of cyclohexene oxidation by Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO is 1.5 times more than Pt0.5Pd0.5/SiO2@GO nanocomposite, without the IL. These results in turn confirmed the critical role of the ionic liquid layer on the surface of catalyst. Its presence not only enhanced the stability of nanoparticles on the surface of support, but also increased the surface/substrate interactions, due to its suitable solvatochromic parameters. In addition, due to the improvement of the stabilization of the reaction intermediates by the IL layer, the Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO catalyst showed the best performance in this reaction. So globally, this synergistic effect between the two metals can improve the catalytic performance of the Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite. 3.3 Influence of the reaction parameters on cyclohexene oxidation 3.3.1 Effect of oxygen pressure The effect of oxygen pressure on the conversion and selectivity of products was investigated over the Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite using acetonitrile as a solvent, and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 12 . It is evident that by increasing the oxygen pressure, the conversion of reaction increased. The results showed that, by increasing the oxygen pressure from 1 bar to 25 bar the conversion of cyclohexene was augmented, up to 65%. Furthermore, the selectivity of 2-cyclohexene-1-one (Cy-one) generation increased from 66% to 93% in this pressure (25 bar). However, by increasing the pressure up to 30 bar, the conversion only slightly increased; this effect can be related to the saturation of the catalytic sites in higher oxygen pressure conditions. [56,57] Beyond that point, when the oxygen pressure was increased, the selectivity of Cy-one decreased, due to the modification of the reaction sites. These results indicated that the reaction preferentially formed allylic oxidation products, especially Cy-one as main product. Therefore, due to the high conversion and selectivity for Cy-one at 25 bar, this pressure was chosen as the optimum oxygen pressure in this reaction for the following steps. 3.3.2 Effect of temperature – Activation energy The influence of temperature on the cyclohexene oxidation over the Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite was investigated by gradually changing the reaction temperature from 60 °C to 90 °C, while the other parameters remained constant. The results are summarized in Fig. 13 . As shown in Fig. 13A, the conversion and distribution of products is depended on the temperature. It was observed that at 60 °C, the conversion of cyclohexene and selectivity towards 2-cyclohexene-1-one (Cy-one) was only about 44% and 71%, respectively, during the 8 h of reaction. An increase in temperature from 60 °C to 90 °C could improve the conversion of cyclohexene, as well as and the selectivity to Cy-one. When the reaction temperature was increased to 80 °C, the conversion of cyclohexene and the selectivity to Cy-one reached up to 65% and 93%, respectively. The obtained results indicated that raising the temperature favors allylic oxidation and Cy-one was obtained as main product. It should be pointed out that at higher temperature than cyclohexene boiling point (83 °C), due to the conversion of cyclohexene into the gas phase, the effective collision with the active sites of the catalyst was decreased, and therefore the conversion of reaction was diminished at 90 °C. Finally, on the basis of the obtained data, this temperature (80 °C) was selected as the optimum temperature for the reaction. Additionally, the first order rate constants of reaction were calculated in different temperatures (60–90 °C). The rate constant of reaction was increased from 1.58 × 10−3 min-1 to 3.35 × 10−3 min-1, when the reaction temperature was varied from 60 °C to 90 °C. Moreover, the activation energy ( E a ) was calculated by applying the Arrhenius equation (eq. 10) where R, T, and A are the ideal gas constant, reaction temperature, and pre-exponential factor, respectively. (10) ln k a p p = - E a R T + ln A The value of E a was determined to be 25.48 kJ mol−1 from the plot of ln (kapp ) versus 1/T as shown in Fig. 13B. The obtained value of energy activation over Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite and other catalysts for oxidation of cyclohexene were compared, and reported in Table 4 . [58–65] This value was lower than values that obtained by the different catalysts, which indicated the high catalytic performance of the as-prepared bimetallic multiphasic nanocomposite towards cyclohexene oxidation. 3.3.3 Effect of the reaction time and catalyst amount As far as the operational parameters are concerned, Fig. 13 (C, and D) summarizes the obtained data concerning the time-resolved evolution of cyclohexene oxidation and catalyst concentration. Fig. 13C illustrates the effect of reaction time on cyclohexene oxidation in the presence of Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite and molecular oxygen as oxidant. As can be seen from the obtained results, the conversion of the reaction was enhanced over reaction time. The cyclohexene conversion was increased quickly during the initial 6 h. After 12 h of reaction, the conversion reached 73% with a Cy-one selectivity of 92%. These results indicated that the selectivity of products is constant over time. Due to the high conversion and selectivity to Cy-one up to 8 h, this reaction time was selected as the optimum reaction duration. Following, in order to investigate the influence of the catalyst amount for the oxidation of cyclohexene, the quantity of Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite was modified from 15 to 30 mg, while the other reaction conditions remained constant (Fig. 13D). The results determined a peak increase of the reaction conversion, when the amount of catalyst was 25 mg. By increasing the amount of catalyst up to 30 mg, no remarkable change was observed in conversion rates. Therefore, 25 mg was selected as a suitable amount of catalyst for this reaction, in the presence of molecular oxygen under proposed conditions. To study the formation and production of 2-cyclohexene-1-one (Cy-one) as main product during the reaction over Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocompoite, FTIR and NMR analyses of resultant product were applied. The FTIR spectra of the resulting sample was recorded and reported in Fig. 14 A. Based on this result, the strong peak was observed at 1719 cm−1 is related to the carbonyl group (CO) in Cy-one that confirmed the formation of Cy-one after the reaction as a main product. Also, the adsorption peaks centered at 2863 cm−1, 2966 cm−1, and 3083 cm−1 are assigned to the C–H groups. According to the 13C NMR analysis (Fig. 14B), the observed resonances at 198.1271, 151.5925, 127.8270, 32.8105, 25.2942, and 24.2888 ppm are in good agreement with the product structure. Moreover, the characteristic signal for the 13C of carbonyl group was detected at δ = 198.1271 ppm. Both of these results confirmed the formation of Cy-one as main product in this reaction over Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite. 3.4 Stability and reusability of the catalyst over consecutive runs The reusability of a catalyst is one of the most important factors for the economy of the system, which makes them useful for commercial applications. For this reason, the reusability and recyclability of the as-prepared Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite was examined in the oxidation reaction, under identical reaction conditions and 5 consecutive runs. After the completion of reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction media by centrifugation, washed twice more by water/ethanol to ensure that substrate removal from the surface of catalyst, and then dried at 60 °C. The dried catalyst was successively used for four additional (total of 5) catalytic runs. As it can be seen from Fig. 15 A, the catalytic activity of recovered catalyst, conversion and selectivity of Cy-one did not change after four catalytic cycles. The as-prepared catalyst showed high durability for the cyclohexene oxidation reaction, with insignificant loss of conversion. This excellent reusability was confirmed by using ICP-AES analysis. The total leaching of Pt and/or Pd metals during the reaction was extremely low; the residual solution was analyzed by ICP and no content of Pt and Pd NPs was observed. The presence of the IL layer on the surface of the catalyst improved the stability of the synthesized NPs. The thermal, morphological and structural stability of the reused catalyst was investigated using TGA, TEM and XRD techniques. The catalyst exhibited high thermal stability after 5 consecutive runs that confirmed the high stability of the IL layer in the as-prepared catalyst after repetitive catalytic cycles. Moreover, this feature can improve the stability of NPs anchoring on the surface of the catalyst and protect the activity of catalyst. As it can also be seen from the obtained results, no significant change in the morphology properties after five cycles was observed in the TEM image of the recovered catalyst (Fig. 15B). Also, the XRD patterns of pristine and recovered catalyst are the same, which indicated that the structure was preserved during the catalytic reactions (Fig. 15C). This high mechanical stability of the as-prepared catalyst indicated that using an IL layer can be an effective method for anchoring NPs on the surface of catalyst. This method can be extended for the preparation of different metal and/or bimetallic multiphasic catalysts. 3.5 Mechanism of cyclohexene oxidation by molecular oxygen Based on the mechanism that was reported in our previous work [55] and the present results the mechanism of cyclohexene ( R H ) oxidation catalyzed by Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite can be described using the following set of reactions (Eqs. 11–17). (11) R H + C a t a l y s t → O 2 R • + H - C a t a l y s t (12) R • + O 2 → R O O • (13) R O O • + R H → R O • + e p o x y c y c l o h e x e n e (14) R O • + R H → R O H + R • (15) R O O • + R • → R O O R (16) R O O • + R O O • → R O H + R = O + O 2 (17) R • + R • → R - R In this mechanism, the formation of radical species from the α-H bond in cyclohexene molecules plays a key role. Briefly, the proposed mechanism involved three steps. [55] At the first step of this mechanism (eq. 11), cyclohexene is converted to the cyclohexenyl radical ( R • ) in the presence of the catalyst (initiation step). In the propagation step (eqs. 12–14), the cyclohexenyl radical reacted with molecular oxygen and cyclohexenyl peroxy radical ( R O O • ) was obtained (eq. 12). This step is the first step of the propagation invoked in the proposed mechanism. Afterwards, the obtained radical can react with another cyclohexene molecule and produce cyclohexenyl hydroperoxide ( R O • ), and epoxycyclohexene (eq. 13). Due to the reaction between cyclohexenyl hydroperoxide ( R O • ) and cyclohexene, 2-cyclohexene-1-ol was obtained. In parallel, the cyclohexenyl radical as another product of this step, can participate in the reaction cycle. At the final steps of this mechanism (eqs. 15–17), all of the radical species that were produced in the reaction can react with each other (termination steps). The cyclohexenyl peroxy molecules can combine with another and the two main products of this reaction including 2-cyclohexene-1-one and 2-cyclohexene-1-ol are produced (eq. 16). In addition, 2-cyclohexene-1-ol as a product can react with molecular oxygen via direct oxidation process, and produce 2-cyclohexene-1-one. This pathway was reported in literature for this reaction over metallic catalysts. [55] By this pathway, the selectivity of ketone product (Cy-one) was increased. The obtained experimental results confirmed that at the optimum conditions, 2-cyclohexene-1-one was found as the main product. For the elucidation of the proposed mechanism, p-benzoquinone was added to the reaction medium as a radical scavenger. In the presence of this radical scavenger, the reaction was completely inhibited. This result confirmed the radical mechanism of this reaction over the as-prepared catalyst (Fig. 15D). The rate constant of oxidation reaction decreased from 2.86 × 10−3 min-1 to 1.72 × 10-4 min-1, in the presence of p-benzoquinone. The obtained results validate the radical mechanism of cyclohexene oxidation over Pt0.5Pd0.5/IL/SiO2@GO nanocomposite, and the proposed pathway. A schematic representation of the mechanism is illustrated in Fig. 16 . It was interesting to note that the BMNPs which were stabilized by the IL layer on the surface of the catalyst, can activate molecular oxygen and provide active sites for cyclohexene oxidation. Also, the multiphasic behavior of the as-prepared catalyst can increase the interaction between the cyclohexene molecules and the catalyst surface, which enhances the efficiency of nanocomposite. Due to the transfer of the cyclohexene molecules from the solvent media to the surface of catalyst and the reaction with BMNPs, the cyclohexenyl peroxy radical was obtained. This radical intermediate has high stability on the IL layer, due to the high polarity of this layer. By the reaction between two intermediates (cyclohexenyl peroxy radicals), the reaction products including 2-cyclohexene-1-one and 2-cyclohexene-1-ol were produced. According to obtained results that were reported in Table 3, the role of IL layer was confirmed as a co-catalyst in this reaction. In the presence of IL layer on the surface of Pt0.5Pd0.5/SiO2@GO catalyst, the conversion of reaction was increased from 50% to 65%, which indicated the critical role of IL in cyclohexene oxidation. 4 Conclusions In the current study, a multiphasic nanocomposite abbreviated as PtxPd1-x/IL/SiO2@GO (x = 0, 0.5 and 1) was prepared, and exhibited excellent catalytic performance in cyclohexene oxidation. The structure, morphology and surface properties of this catalyst were examined by various characterization techniques, which revealed the key components of the success in this process. Among of the different catalysts (monometallic and bimetallic), the bimetallic NPs (BMNPs) had a remarkable activity in this reaction, which is related to the synergistic effect between two metals. The addition of the ionic liquid layer on the surface of catalyst not only provided a multiphasic catalyst with both heterogeneous and homogenous properties, but also increased the stability of the reaction intermediates on the surface of nanocomposite, due to the high polarity and hydrogen bond acceptor ability. The influence of different experimental conditions including molecular oxygen pressure, reaction time, temperature and catalyst amount were studied, in order to find the optimum conditions for obtaining the highest selectivity and conversion in this reaction. Our results indicated that presence of IL layer on the surface of nanocomposite can be greatly enhanced the BMNPs performance. Furthermore, this nanocomposite displayed remarkably high stability in the oxidation reaction, with negligible loss of catalytic activity after five runs. The results confirmed that the coating of ionic liquids as a co-catalyst on the surface of SiO2@GO, can improve the catalytic performance. This coating method can be developed for the preparation of new multiphasic materials as low-cost and recyclable catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In this work, PtxPd1-x (x = 0, 0.5, and 1) nanoparticles (NPs) were synthesized on the surface of SiO2@graphene oxide which covered by 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate ([bmim] PF6) ionic liquid (IL) layer. FT-IR spectroscopy, zeta potential, CHN elemental analysis, XRD, XPS, SEM, EDX, TEM, TGA, BET, and ICP-AES techniques were applied for the characterization of the multiphasic catalyst. The as-prepared nanocomposite was used as an effective heterogeneous catalyst for the oxidation of cyclohexene by molecular oxygen, as a green oxidant. Different experimental conditions such as oxygen pressure, reaction time, reaction temperature and amount of catalyst were investigated in this reaction. The bimetallic NPs showed the best catalytic activity in this reaction. The conversion and selectivity of 2-cyclohexene-1-one as main product were obtained to be 65% and 93% respectively, when the reaction was carried at 80 °C for 8 h. In the as-made multiphasic catalyst, IL layer not only enhanced the stability of NPs on the surface of catalyst, but also increased the catalytic performance due to the stabilization of the reaction intermediates. Among the different solvathochromic parameters, the normalized polarity ( E T N ) and the hydrogen-bond acceptor ability (β) of IL are the most important properties which improve the role of the IL as a co-catalyst in this reaction. This multiphasic catalyst, which has the advantages of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalytic systems, can be easily separated from the reaction media and reused for five consecutive runs without losing the catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Supported PtxPd1-x bimetallic nanoparticles on ionic liquid-functionalized SiO2@graphene oxide nanocomposite and its application as an effective multiphasic catalyst
